qas.question: To what location is Selenizza bitumen native?
What is it about the mine that is unusual?
In what way is Selenizza bitumen geologically different than bitumen found in sands?

context: Selenizza is a naturally occurring solid hydrocarbon bitumen found in the native asphalt deposit of <a0_0>Selenice, in Albania<a0_0/>, the only European asphalt mine <a1_0>still in use<a1_0/>. The <a2_0><b7_0>rock asphalt<b7_0/><a2_0/> is found in the form of <a4_0>veins<a4_0/>, filling cracks in a more or less horizontal direction. The <b8_0>bitumen<b8_0/> content varies from <a3_0>83% to 92%<a3_0/> (soluble in carbon disulphide), with a penetration value near to zero and a softening point (ring & ball) around 120 °C. The <b6_0>insoluble matter<b6_0/>, consisting mainly of silica ore, ranges from <b5_0>8% to 17%<b5_0/>.
